elements.content: Three rare examples of extended inorganic materials possessing a cationic charge on the host have been successfully synthesized hydrothermally. The first structure consists of two-dimensional lead fluoride [Pb9F16]2+ sheets with perchlorate anions occupying the interlayer space. The material is a higher symmetry polytype of our previously reported lead fluoride nitrate Pb3F5·NO3. Two new isoreticular layered metal−organic frameworks have also been discovered with cationic lead fluoride [Pb2F2]2+ layers pillared by 3- and 4-carbon chain alkylenedisulfonate molecules. Each structure was characterized by powder and single-crystal X-ray diffraction and thermogravimetric analysis. The thermal stability increases with the alkylene chain length of the linker molecule. The syntheses require the addition of perchloric acid to the reaction mixture. An improved synthesis for our previously reported lead fluoride polytype pillared by ethanedisulfonate in terms of increased yield and purity was also realized using perchloric acid.

Two new isoreticular layered metal-organic frameworks have also been discovered with cationic lead fluoride [Pb2F2]2+ layers pillared by 3- and 4-carbon chain alkylenedisulfonate molecules. Each structure was characterized by powder and single-crystal X-ray diffraction and thermogravimetric analysis. The thermal stability increases with the alkylene chain length of the linker molecule. elements.content: We have discovered three closely related inorganic and hybrid inorganic−organic cationic layered materials. The first structure consists of cationic lead fluoride [Pb9F16]2+ triple layers with perchlorate anions between the layers balancing the charge. The other two materials have isostructural [Pb2F2]2+ lead fluoride layers, pillared by propylene- and butylene-disulfonate molecules.

The first structure consists of cationic lead fluoride [Pb9F16]2+ triple layers with perchlorate anions between the layers balancing the charge. The other two materials have isostructural [Pb2F2]2+ lead fluoride layers, pillared by propylene- and butylene-disulfonate molecules.

elements.content: We are interested in creating a new class of nanoporous cationic inorganic materials for anion intercalation and heterogeneous catalysis. The potential applications are based on the cationic charge of the host layers and the extra-framework anions that reside in the galleries of the structure. The vast majority of three-dimensional (3D) porous inorganic structure types known to date are either anionic or charge-neutral, with cationic or neutral guests. Two cationic two-dimensional (2D) materials were reported by Halasyamani and co-workers. The chloride anion present in the channels of these mixed metal oxychlorides (Te4M3O15·Cl, M = Nb5+ or Ta5+), however, cannot be removed or exchanged without decomposition of the host material. There is also an isostructural naturally occurring mineral [francisite, Cu3Bi(SeO3)2O2·Cl], where the extra-framework chloride ions reside in the tunnels. Again, this structure is not suitable as an intercalation material because the free diameter of the channels is very limited. The anions cannot be easily dislodged from the host, though smaller halides such as fluoride can be introduced into the structures.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

We are interested in creating a new class of nanoporous cationic inorganic materials for anion intercalation and heterogeneous catalysis. The potential applications are based on the cationic charge of the host layers and the extra-framework anions that reside in the galleries of the structure. The vast majority of three-dimensional (3D) porous inorganic structure types known to date are either anionic or charge-neutral, with cationic or neutral guests. Two cationic two-dimensional (2D) materials were reported by Halasyamani and co-workers. The chloride anion present in the channels of these mixed metal oxychlorides (Te4M3O15⋅Cl, M = Nb5+ or Ta5+), however, cannot be removed or exchanged without decomposition of the host material. There is also an isostructural naturally occurring mineral [francisite, Cu3Bi(SeO3)2O2⋅Cl], where the extra-framework chloride ions reside in the tunnels. Again, this structure is not suitable as an intercalation material because the free diameter of the channels is very limited. The anions cannot be easily dislodged from the host, though smaller halides such as fluoride can be introduced into the structures.

elements.content: Prior to our efforts, there were very few known layered (2D) cationic inorganic structure types. The layered double hydroxides (LDHs) are very well studied and continue to be an area of intense research. LDHs can be synthesized under ambient conditions or solvothermally by addition of base to an aqueous solution containing the precursor metal salts. This class of materials, when naturally occurring, are known as hydrotalcites or anionic clays and the cationic layers are isostructural with the mineral brucite, Mg(OH)2. The layers in brucite consist of edge-sharing Mg(OH)6 octahedra with hydrogen atoms capping the layers. When a fraction of the Mg2+ cations are replaced by a trivalent cation (e.g., Al3+), the layers are rendered cationic, necessitating charge balancing anions between the layers. A variety of di- and trivalent metals can be used to make synthetic LDHs, within a range of ionic radii. Related 2D structures also exist, such as the metal hydroxynitrates, hydroxyacetates, and hydroxyhalides. These are polytypes of the LDH-type structures, where the hydroxides of the brucite-like layers can be functionalized with the different groups. For example, a cobalt hydroxide structure discovered by Cheetham and co-workers consists of brucite-like layers where a fraction of the octahedral sites are replaced by Co(II) tetrahedra above and below the plane of the layer. It would seem that the metal to oxygen ratio combined with the capping of the octahedra with hydrogen is one of the only previously known ways to render an inorganic material cationic.

elements.content: There are many potential applications for highly stable materials that can selectively exchange extra-framework anions, such as acid and/or base catalysis, waste-stream purification, and drug delivery. The materials currently used for anion-exchange are organic resins and organozeolites (surfactant coated zeolites), which are generally not stable above ca. 150 °C and have limited chemical stability. These types of materials are therefore not suitable for heterogeneous catalysis or treatment of corrosive wastewater.
elements.clean_text: There are many potential applications for highly stable materials that can selectively exchange extra-framework anions, such as acid and/or base catalysis, waste-stream purification, and drug delivery. The materials currently used for anion-exchange are organic resins and organozeolites (surfactant coated zeolites), which are generally not stable above ca. 150 °C and have limited chemical stability. These types of materials are therefore not suitable for heterogeneous catalysis or treatment of corrosive wastewater.

elements.content: Our approach focuses on the use of anionic structure directing agents (SDAs) and excludes any potential cationic SDAs. We are currently exploring the late p-block metals for their diverse connectivity and umbrella-like geometry which allows formation of low-coordinate cationic sites. We have been exploring the lanthanide series for similar reasons, as well as their fluorescent and magnetic properties. We have discovered a new class of cationic inorganic materials, beginning with the lead fluoride structure Pb3F5·NO3 (BING-5). We also recently reported a 2D cationic antimony oxyhydroxide layered material [Sb4O4(OH)2][(CH2)2(SO3)2]·H2O (SLUG-5) that was useful as an inexpensive, reusable Lewis acid heterogeneous catalyst.

We have discovered a new class of cationic inorganic materials, beginning with the lead fluoride structure Pb3F5⋅NO3 (BING-5). We also recently reported a 2D cationic antimony oxyhydroxide layered material [Sb4O4(OH)2][(CH2)2(SO3)2]⋅H2O (SLUG-5) that was useful as an inexpensive, reusable Lewis acid heterogeneous catalyst.

elements.content: Here we report three cationic structures (Table ): (i) Pb9F16·(ClO4)2, a 2D cationic layered material consisting of positively charged lead fluoride triple layers sandwiching interlamellar perchlorate anions; (ii) Pb2F2[(CH2)3(SO3)2]; and (iii) Pb2F2[(CH2)4(SO3)2], which have isostructural layers pillared by propylene- and butylene-disulfonate molecules. These two new hybrid inorganic−organic structures are isostructural to our previously reported Pb2F2[(CH2)2(SO3)2], differing by the chain length of the alkanedisulfonate linkers. A new synthesis method involving addition of perchloric acid to the reaction mixture improves the yield and purity of the materials.

These two new hybrid inorganic-organic structures are isostructural to our previously reported Pb2F2[(CH2)2(SO3)2], differing by the chain length of the alkanedisulfonate linkers. A new synthesis method involving addition of perchloric acid to the reaction mixture improves the yield and purity of the materials.

elements.content: Pb 9 F 16 ·(ClO 4 ) 2 (which we denote SLUG-10, for University of California, Santa Cruz, Structure No. 10) was synthesized hydrothermally under autogenous pressure. Solid PbF2 (ca. 5 μm powder, 99+ %, Acros) and perchloric acid (70% in H2O, Acros) were added to water in a 1:2.75:200 molar ratio, respectively. The water in the perchloric acid solution was accounted for in the final mixture of reagents to preserve the molar ratios. The total volume of the reaction mixture was scaled to 10 mL and added to a Teflon-lined autoclave. The 15 mL capacity autoclave (constructed in-house) was filled to ca. 2/3 capacity and heated statically in an oven at 150 °C for 48 h. The average yield was 79% (0.89 g). Elemental analysis was performed by Intertek USA Inc. d/b/a QTI, Whitehouse, NJ: F: 12.98% (12.84% theoretical), Cl: 2.60% (2.99%).

Experimental Section

Synthesis

 Pb  9  F  16  ⋅(ClO  4  )  2  (which we denote SLUG-10, for University of California, Santa Cruz, Structure No. 10) was synthesized hydrothermally under autogenous pressure. Solid PbF2 (ca. 5 μm powder, 99+ %, Acros) and perchloric acid (70% in H2O, Acros) were added to water in a 1:2.75:200 molar ratio, respectively. The water in the perchloric acid solution was accounted for in the final mixture of reagents to preserve the molar ratios. The total volume of the reaction mixture was scaled to 10 mL and added to a Teflon-lined autoclave. The 15 mL capacity autoclave (constructed in-house) was filled to ca. 2/3 capacity and heated statically in an oven at 150 °C for 48 h. The average yield was 79% (0.89 g). Elemental analysis was performed by Intertek USA Inc. d/b/a QTI, Whitehouse, NJ: F: 12.98% (12.84% theoretical), Cl: 2.60% (2.99%).

elements.content: Pb 2 F 2 [(CH 2 ) 2 (SO 3 ) 2 ] (SLUG-6) was synthesized as above using PbF2, H2[(CH2)2(SO3)2] (95%, TCI America) or Na2[(CH2)2(SO3)2] (>98%, TCI America), perchloric acid (70% in H2O, Acros), and water in a 1:2:2.5:200 molar ratio. The total volume of the reaction mixture was scaled to 10 mL and added to a Teflon-lined autoclave. The 15 mL capacity autoclave was filled to ca. 2/3 capacity and heated statically in an oven at 150 °C for 48 h. The average yield for the synthesis using the acid form of ethanedisulfonic acid was 83% (0.73 g) compared to 80% (0.70 g) for the previously reported synthesis which did not use perchlorate. The yield was 86% (0.75 g) using the disodium salt of ethanedisulfonate.

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data was recorded using a Rigaku MiniFlex II Plus powder diffractometer with Cu−Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). The irradiated area of the sample was a constant 4 mm2 by variable slit mechanism. Single crystal data were recorded using a Bruker APEX II CCD area detector X-ray diffractometer using graphite monochromated Mo−Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The structures were solved by direct methods and expanded routinely. The models were refined by full-matrix least-squares analysis of F 2 against all reflections. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal displacement parameters. Thermal parameters for the hydrogen atoms were tied to the isotropic thermal parameter of the atom to which they are bonded. Programs used: APEX-II v2.1.4; SHELXTL v6.14; Diamond v3.1e. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) analysis was carried out using a TA Instruments 2050 TGA with N2(g) purge.
elements.clean_text:
Instrumental

Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data was recorded using a Rigaku MiniFlex II Plus powder diffractometer with Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). The irradiated area of the sample was a constant 4 mm2 by variable slit mechanism. Single crystal data were recorded using a Bruker APEX II CCD area detector X-ray diffractometer using graphite monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The structures were solved by direct methods and expanded routinely. The models were refined by full-matrix least-squares analysis of F 2 against all reflections. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal displacement parameters. Thermal parameters for the hydrogen atoms were tied to the isotropic thermal parameter of the atom to which they are bonded. Programs used: APEX-II v2.1.4; SHELXTL v6.14; Diamond v3.1e. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) analysis was carried out using a TA Instruments 2050 TGA with N2(g) purge.

Pb4.5F8·ClO4 (SLUG-10) forms at 150 °C under hydrothermal conditions. The resulting crystals are large area (avg ∼ 1.6 mm2) thin colorless plates. Increasing the mole ratio of water resulted in somewhat higher yields (from about 20−30% for 100 mol of H2O to 60−80% for 200 mol of H2O) and higher purity (average 96% SLUG-10); α-PbF2 was present in only small amounts (4% average), as determined by PXRD. The overall average percent yield of SLUG-10 with 200 mol of H2O is 79%, and the yield of α-PbF2 is less than 1% of total yield as determined by PXRD. The remaining lead fluoride and perchloric acid presumably remain in the aqueous reaction solution.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Structure

SLUG-10

Pb4.5F8⋅ClO4 (SLUG-10) forms at 150 °C under hydrothermal conditions. The resulting crystals are large area (avg ~ 1.6 mm2) thin colorless plates. Increasing the mole ratio of water resulted in somewhat higher yields (from about 20-30% for 100 mol of H2O to 60-80% for 200 mol of H2O) and higher purity (average 96% SLUG-10); α-PbF2 was present in only small amounts (4% average), as determined by PXRD. The overall average percent yield of SLUG-10 with 200 mol of H2O is 79%, and the yield of α-PbF2 is less than 1% of total yield as determined by PXRD. The remaining lead fluoride and perchloric acid presumably remain in the aqueous reaction solution.

The structure of SLUG-10 consists of triple layers of overall stoichiometry [Pb9F16]2+, which interact electrostatically with the interlamellar perchlorate anions (Figures and , Table ). The three distinct lead centers all exhibit different coordination geometries. The central Pb4F8 layer is charge-neutral, with lead centers Pb(1) coordinated by six fluorine atoms within the layer F(1). Two additional fluorides from the two outer layers give Pb(1) a regular eight-coordinate square-prismatic geometry. The other lead in the central layer Pb(2) is seven-coordinate, a square prismatic geometry with one corner removed and residing on a 3-fold axis. The two outer surface layers consist of asymmetric five-coordinate lead centers Pb(3) with overall formula [Pb5F8]2+. Two of the fluorine atoms within this layer are located on the 3-fold axes [F(2) and F(4)], while F(3) and Pb(3) are located in general positions. The coordination sphere of the lead atom in the outer layers Pb(3) is not fully saturated. Without the oxygen stabilizing the outer asymmetric uncoordinated lead atoms, the structure is not stable and the layers collapse into α-PbF2. If the structure can be pillared or stabilized, the open coordination sites on Pb2+ could possibly be used for catalysis.

elements.content: SLUG-10 is different from our previously published BING-5 in that it is templated by a new anion and is crystallographically distinct in several respects. First, the higher symmetry rhombohedral R3̅ space group for SLUG-10 is on the other end of the crystallographic spectrum versus the low symmetry cell setting of triclinic P1̅ for BING-5. The unit cell of SLUG-10 is the rhombohedral obverse triple cell with hexagonal axes. BING-5 contains no less than 13 crystallographically inequivalent lead atoms in the asymmetric unit versus only three in SLUG-10. Second, the two cationic outer layers in the triple layer of SLUG-10 have a far more regular connectivity and higher symmetry than those of BING-5; there is a 3-fold rotation axis centered on Pb(1) (the origin of the unit cell) that is not present in BING-5. Third, the interlamellar anion arrays are more widely spaced: the nearest oxygen−oxygen distance for the perchlorate anions in SLUG-10 is 4.2269(91) Å versus 2.9234(242) Å for BING-5. The closest distance between perchlorate oxygen and lead in SLUG-10 is 3.0612(67) between the Pb(3) and O(2) centers and is thus considered a “long” electrostatic contact. The shortest oxygen to lead contact in BING-5 is 2.7821(216) Å. The perchlorate anions also have higher symmetry; chlorine and O(2) both reside on the same 3-fold rotation axis. In contrast, the nitrate anions of BING-5 do not lie on any special positions. In general, BING-5 has only the inversion symmetry characteristic of its space group. SLUG-10 is an inherently high symmetry structure that is geometrically very distinct compared to known cationic layered structures such as the LDHs.

elements.content: Pb2F2[(CH2)3(SO3)2] (SLUG-11) and Pb2F2[(CH2)4(SO3)2] (SLUG-12) form under mild hydrothermal conditions. Both structures can be synthesized between and including the temperatures of 150 and 175 °C. Relatively high yields are obtained in both cases (average 80% for SLUG-11 and 78% for SLUG-12). The yields of SLUG-6 are higher than previously reported using the new synthesis method involving the addition of perchloric acid to the reaction solution.
elements.clean_text:
SLUG-11 and -12

Pb2F2[(CH2)3(SO3)2] (SLUG-11) and Pb2F2[(CH2)4(SO3)2] (SLUG-12) form under mild hydrothermal conditions. Both structures can be synthesized between and including the temperatures of 150 and 175 °C. Relatively high yields are obtained in both cases (average 80% for SLUG-11 and 78% for SLUG-12). The yields of SLUG-6 are higher than previously reported using the new synthesis method involving the addition of perchloric acid to the reaction solution.

Pb2F2[(CH2)3(SO3)2] is made up of single layers of lead fluoride ([Pb2F2]2+) pillared by propylenedisulfonate molecules (Figures and ). SLUG-12 is composed of layers that are isostructural to SLUG-11, pillared instead by butylenedisulfonate molecules. Both of these structures are isoreticular to SLUG-6, differing only in the chain length of the α,ω-alkanedisulfonate linkers. The coordination geometry of the lead atoms are distorted five coordinate. The fluorine atoms are triply bridging in a distorted tetrahedral geometry with one corner vacant. One of the oxygen atoms on each end of the disulfonate molecules is not covalently bonded to lead but can be considered a long contact. The S(1)−O(2) bond [1.471(3) Å] in SLUG-11 is longer than the other two S−O bonds, S(1)−O(1) [1.463(3) Å] and S(1)−O(3) [1.466(3) Å], which suggests that O(2) is not bonded to lead and remains negatively charged (Table ). The distance from O(3) to Pb(1) is 2.8830(28) Å in SLUG-11, and for SLUG-12 the corresponding distance is 2.8651(39) Å. By a search of the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD), these bond distances are beyond the range of covalent bonding for lead and oxygen (average Pb−O distance: 2.604 ± 0.211 Å).

elements.content: Subtle differences in the crystallographic symmetry distinguish these two structures from one another and highlight a trend beginning with SLUG-6. The even-numbered alkyl chain disulfonate structures have symmetry elements between the carbon atoms in the chain, while the odd-numbered carbon chain structure has the symmetry element on the center carbon atom. Specifically, C(2) in SLUG-11 sits on a mirror plane parallel with the b−c plane (Figure a,b). In SLUG-12, the mirror plane is centered on the bond between C(2) and C(2)A, also parallel with the b−c plane (Figure b,c).

elements.content: The PXRD pattern of SLUG-10 shown in Figure is of a sonicated ethanol dispersion of the crystals drop-cast onto a glass slide. The intensity was scaled down by a factor of 0.15 to bring the data to a comparable scale with the other powder patterns in the graph. Because of the extremely anisotropic nature of the layered structure, the majority basal peak and higher order basal reflections appear in the powder pattern, but most of the other reflections are absent or very weak due to preferred orientation (Figure ). The (116) reflection is the only intense peak that is not a multiple of (003). The powder patterns of SLUG-11 and SLUG-12 are also shown in Figure . The theoretical patterns match the experimental patterns closely. An impurity in SLUG-11 is observed at 12.26° 2θ.

elements.content: The TGA trace of SLUG-10 shows thermal stability up to ca. 456 °C, where the calculated onset of weight loss occurs (Figure ). The small weight loss of ∼1% with onset at ca. 100 °C is most likely due to physisorbed water. The only significant weight loss step of 6% beginning at 456 °C is attributed to 71% of the perchlorate anions being evolved from the galleries of the structure (8.4% expected if 100% of the perchlorate anions). The structure becomes destabilized as the anions are driven out, transforming the layers into α-PbF2 (ICDD PDF No. 41-1086) as evidenced by ex situ heating to 450 °C and subsequent PXRD. The major weight loss at ca. 860 °C and continuing through the entire trace up to the maximum measurable temperature of 1000 °C is indicative of the thermal decomposition of the PbF2 structure. From the literature, the α-PbF2 structure is stable to 500 °C, where gradual weight loss begins and about 10% of the mass is lost when it reaches 800 °C. Presumably, fluorine (F2) is being evolved and the structure is condensing into lead metal.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Characterization

The TGA trace of SLUG-10 shows thermal stability up to ca. 456 °C, where the calculated onset of weight loss occurs (Figure ). The small weight loss of ~1% with onset at ca. 100 °C is most likely due to physisorbed water. The only significant weight loss step of 6% beginning at 456 °C is attributed to 71% of the perchlorate anions being evolved from the galleries of the structure (8.4% expected if 100% of the perchlorate anions). The structure becomes destabilized as the anions are driven out, transforming the layers into α-PbF2 (ICDD PDF No. 41-1086) as evidenced by ex situ heating to 450 °C and subsequent PXRD. The major weight loss at ca. 860 °C and continuing through the entire trace up to the maximum measurable temperature of 1000 °C is indicative of the thermal decomposition of the PbF2 structure. From the literature, the α-PbF2 structure is stable to 500 °C, where gradual weight loss begins and about 10% of the mass is lost when it reaches 800 °C. Presumably, fluorine (F2) is being evolved and the structure is condensing into lead metal.

elements.content: The TGA trace of SLUG-11 shows thermal stability up to ca. 445 °C (Figure ). After the major weight loss just beyond 500 °C, about 75% of the original mass remains. This corresponds to 81% of the propanedisulfonate molecules (theoretically 31% of entire structure). The TGA trace of SLUG-12 shows that the structure remains thermally stable up to ca. 454 °C (Figure ). The major weight loss step leaves about 73% of the original mass. This would correspond to 84% of the butanedisulfonate molecules (32% theoretical). Both of the structures were found to be α-PbF2 after ex situ heating to 500 °C and subsequent PXRD measurement. These results are consistent with the TGA measurements of our previously reported SLUG-6 structure, where the organic pillars are calcined out of the structure, constituting the major weight loss event. For both structures, there are gradual and relatively sudden weight gain steps observed around the temperature ranges from 250 °C to the major mass loss events (445 and 454 °C) and also ca. 800 °C up to around 900 °C, respectively. These events may be due to uptake of N2(g).

elements.content: It was discovered serendipitously that perchloric acid added to the reaction mixture containing lead fluoride and ethanedisulfonic acid or the disodium salt of ethanedisulfonate results in formation of SLUG-6. The aim of the original synthetic attempt was to find a structure that combined the discrete cationic layers and interlamellar perchlorate anions of SLUG-10 with the alkylenedisulfonate pillars of SLUG-6. Instead, it was found that SLUG-6 formed in higher yield and purity than the originally reported synthetic procedure. Before it was discovered that perchlorate would act as a stabilizer, attempts to synthesize lead fluoride layered structures using longer chain length alkanedisulfonates were not successful. The product consisted of PbF2 and the organic template in a multiphase powder. This new synthesis also allowed us to rationally design the two new structures. It appears that the perchloric acid in the reaction solution acts as a stabilizer much like the fluoride ion is known to act as a mineralizer for zeolites and other materials. Also, the “non-coordinating” nature of perchlorate anion facilitates the formation of discrete cationic layers in Pb9F16·(ClO4)2.
elements.clean_text:
Role of Perchloric Acid in the Rational Design of the Structures

It was discovered serendipitously that perchloric acid added to the reaction mixture containing lead fluoride and ethanedisulfonic acid or the disodium salt of ethanedisulfonate results in formation of SLUG-6. The aim of the original synthetic attempt was to find a structure that combined the discrete cationic layers and interlamellar perchlorate anions of SLUG-10 with the alkylenedisulfonate pillars of SLUG-6. Instead, it was found that SLUG-6 formed in higher yield and purity than the originally reported synthetic procedure. Before it was discovered that perchlorate would act as a stabilizer, attempts to synthesize lead fluoride layered structures using longer chain length alkanedisulfonates were not successful. The product consisted of PbF2 and the organic template in a multiphase powder. This new synthesis also allowed us to rationally design the two new structures. It appears that the perchloric acid in the reaction solution acts as a stabilizer much like the fluoride ion is known to act as a mineralizer for zeolites and other materials. Also, the "non-coordinating" nature of perchlorate anion facilitates the formation of discrete cationic layers in Pb9F16⋅(ClO4)2.

elements.content: Attempts to exchange the interlamellar perchlorate anions for permanganate, p-tosylate, and benzoate resulted in decomposition of the host layers into α-PbF2. The reaction of SLUG-10 in the presence of solutions of these anions goes to completion within 24 h. The attempted exchange and reaction with dichromate anion proceeded more slowly and could be followed by PXRD and UV−vis (Figure ). UV−vis spectra show the removal of dichromate from the solution after 24, 48, and 72 h of soaking. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis of the resultant crystals also confirmed the transformation of the structure into α-PbF2. This is also confirmed by PXRD. The crystals were mounted and orientation matrices were obtained. Whether multiple crystals from the same experiment, or different exchange experiments using various anions, the selected crystal always indexed to the α-PbF2 unit cell.
elements.clean_text:
Anion Exchange Studies with SLUG-10

Attempts to exchange the interlamellar perchlorate anions for permanganate, p-tosylate, and benzoate resulted in decomposition of the host layers into α-PbF2. The reaction of SLUG-10 in the presence of solutions of these anions goes to completion within 24 h. The attempted exchange and reaction with dichromate anion proceeded more slowly and could be followed by PXRD and UV-vis (Figure ). UV-vis spectra show the removal of dichromate from the solution after 24, 48, and 72 h of soaking. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis of the resultant crystals also confirmed the transformation of the structure into α-PbF2. This is also confirmed by PXRD. The crystals were mounted and orientation matrices were obtained. Whether multiple crystals from the same experiment, or different exchange experiments using various anions, the selected crystal always indexed to the α-PbF2 unit cell.

elements.content: Originally, BING-5 showed initial evidence of anion exchange for benzoate. It was later realized through further investigation that the structure was actually being transformed into a layered metal−organic framework with benzoate. SLUG-10 does not form the same layered metal−organic framework structure when exposed to benzoic acid. The reason must have to do with the fact that there are different anions in the interlayer space. It is also likely that the greater spacing of the anions in SLUG-10 versus BING-5 renders the structure less chemically stable.
elements.clean_text: Originally, BING-5 showed initial evidence of anion exchange for benzoate. It was later realized through further investigation that the structure was actually being transformed into a layered metal-organic framework with benzoate. SLUG-10 does not form the same layered metal-organic framework structure when exposed to benzoic acid. The reason must have to do with the fact that there are different anions in the interlayer space. It is also likely that the greater spacing of the anions in SLUG-10 versus BING-5 renders the structure less chemically stable.

elements.content: Preliminary data shows that the cationic layers in SLUG-10 can be exfoliated in 25% aqueous perchloric acid (pH = 0.97) solution as evidenced by the Tyndall effect. Simply soaking the crystals in the solution allows the layers to separate into nanosheets within a few minutes without sonicating or agitating. The suspension remains stable for over 1 week; that is, the Tyndall effect is still observed, disappearing after about eight days. Not only is perchlorate necessary for formation of the structure, but it is also the key to stabilizing the layers, allowing them to be suspended in solution.
elements.clean_text: Preliminary data shows that the cationic layers in SLUG-10 can be exfoliated in 25% aqueous perchloric acid (pH = 0.97) solution as evidenced by the Tyndall effect. Simply soaking the crystals in the solution allows the layers to separate into nanosheets within a few minutes without sonicating or agitating. The suspension remains stable for over 1 week; that is, the Tyndall effect is still observed, disappearing after about eight days. Not only is perchlorate necessary for formation of the structure, but it is also the key to stabilizing the layers, allowing them to be suspended in solution.

elements.content: SLUG-10 is the third cationic purely inorganic structure that our group has reported to date, all of which are unlike any previously discovered cationic material. The connectivity of the frameworks and the formation of triple layers are very distinct when compared to existing cationic layered structures such as LDH-type compounds. Attempts to exchange the interlamellar anions resulted in the transformation of the host layers back into the starting material. It is likely, however, that suitable pre- or postsynthetic conditions can be discovered to transform the 2D structure into a pillared nanoporous solid. Because of the inherently noncoordinating character of perchlorate, such a scenario would result in a highly stable anion-exchangeable structure with a multitude of possible host−guest applications. Preliminary data indicates that exfoliation of the layers is occurring; it may be possible to reassemble the layers with different anions between them. We are investigating the possibilities for reassembly and/or layer-by-layer deposition using SLUG-10 nanosheets.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

SLUG-10 is the third cationic purely inorganic structure that our group has reported to date, all of which are unlike any previously discovered cationic material. The connectivity of the frameworks and the formation of triple layers are very distinct when compared to existing cationic layered structures such as LDH-type compounds. Attempts to exchange the interlamellar anions resulted in the transformation of the host layers back into the starting material. It is likely, however, that suitable pre- or postsynthetic conditions can be discovered to transform the 2D structure into a pillared nanoporous solid. Because of the inherently noncoordinating character of perchlorate, such a scenario would result in a highly stable anion-exchangeable structure with a multitude of possible host-guest applications. Preliminary data indicates that exfoliation of the layers is occurring; it may be possible to reassemble the layers with different anions between them. We are investigating the possibilities for reassembly and/or layer-by-layer deposition using SLUG-10 nanosheets.

elements.content: SLUG-11 and -12 are the second and third in a series of structures with [Pb2F2]2+ layers pillared by varying the alkyl chain length of α,ω-alkanedisulfonates. The role of perchloric acid in the formation of these materials has been investigated. It seems that the perchlorate anion acts as a stabilizer in the syntheses of these materials. These structures represent significant progress toward the discovery of a highly stable porous cationic material that can be used in a number of anion intercalation based applications. Our target material is a mix between these two structure types, where the pillars would confer stability to the layers but with enough open space for the anions to be exchangeable. Although the pillars are more densely packed than would be desirable for pore volume sufficient to allow guest diffusion, it may be possible to tune the density of the pillars in this system to realize our original target of anion intercalation.

cln_elements.content:
Pb 9 F 16 ·(ClO 4 ) 2 (which we denote SLUG-10, for University of California, Santa Cruz, Structure No. 10) was synthesized hydrothermally under autogenous pressure. Solid PbF2 (ca. 5 μm powder, 99+ %, Acros) and perchloric acid (70% in H2O, Acros) were added to water in a 1:2.75:200 molar ratio, respectively. The water in the perchloric acid solution was accounted for in the final mixture of reagents to preserve the molar ratios. The total volume of the reaction mixture was scaled to 10 mL and added to a Teflon-lined autoclave. The 15 mL capacity autoclave (constructed in-house) was filled to ca. 2/3 capacity and heated statically in an oven at 150 °C for 48 h. The average yield was 79% (0.89 g). Elemental analysis was performed by Intertek USA Inc. d/b/a QTI, Whitehouse, NJ: F: 12.98% (12.84% theoretical), Cl: 2.60% (2.99%).

Pb 2 F 2 [(CH 2 ) 2 (SO 3 ) 2 ] (SLUG-6) was synthesized as above using PbF2, H2[(CH2)2(SO3)2] (95%, TCI America) or Na2[(CH2)2(SO3)2] (>98%, TCI America), perchloric acid (70% in H2O, Acros), and water in a 1:2:2.5:200 molar ratio. The total volume of the reaction mixture was scaled to 10 mL and added to a Teflon-lined autoclave. The 15 mL capacity autoclave was filled to ca. 2/3 capacity and heated statically in an oven at 150 °C for 48 h. The average yield for the synthesis using the acid form of ethanedisulfonic acid was 83% (0.73 g) compared to 80% (0.70 g) for the previously reported synthesis which did not use perchlorate. The yield was 86% (0.75 g) using the disodium salt of ethanedisulfonate.

Pb 2 F 2 [(CH 2 ) 3 (SO 3 ) 2 ] (SLUG-11) was synthesized as SLUG-6 above using PbF2, Na2[(CH2)3(SO3)2] (99%, Acros), perchloric acid, and water in a 1:2:2.5:200 molar ratio. The mixture was heated at 150 °C for 48 h. The average yield was 80% (0.64 g). Elemental analysis: C: 5.42% (5.50%), H: 0.62% (0.92%), N: < 0.05% (0%).

Pb 2 F 2 [(CH 2 ) 4 (SO 3 ) 2 ] (SLUG-12) was synthesized as above using PbF2, Na2[(CH2)4(SO3)2] (>98%, TCI America), perchloric acid and water in a 1:2:2.5:200 molar ratio. The mixture was heated at 175 °C for 48 h. The average yield was 78% (0.70 g). Elemental analysis: C: 7.09% (7.19%), H: 1.03% (1.21%), N: 0.23% (0%).

cln_elements.content:
The TGA trace of SLUG-10 shows thermal stability up to ca. 456 °C, where the calculated onset of weight loss occurs (Figure ). The small weight loss of ∼1% with onset at ca. 100 °C is most likely due to physisorbed water. The only significant weight loss step of 6% beginning at 456 °C is attributed to 71% of the perchlorate anions being evolved from the galleries of the structure (8.4% expected if 100% of the perchlorate anions). The structure becomes destabilized as the anions are driven out, transforming the layers into α-PbF2 (ICDD PDF No. 41-1086) as evidenced by ex situ heating to 450 °C and subsequent PXRD. The major weight loss at ca. 860 °C and continuing through the entire trace up to the maximum measurable temperature of 1000 °C is indicative of the thermal decomposition of the PbF2 structure. From the literature, the α-PbF2 structure is stable to 500 °C, where gradual weight loss begins and about 10% of the mass is lost when it reaches 800 °C. Presumably, fluorine (F2) is being evolved and the structure is condensing into lead metal.

The TGA trace of SLUG-11 shows thermal stability up to ca. 445 °C (Figure ). After the major weight loss just beyond 500 °C, about 75% of the original mass remains. This corresponds to 81% of the propanedisulfonate molecules (theoretically 31% of entire structure). The TGA trace of SLUG-12 shows that the structure remains thermally stable up to ca. 454 °C (Figure ). The major weight loss step leaves about 73% of the original mass. This would correspond to 84% of the butanedisulfonate molecules (32% theoretical). Both of the structures were found to be α-PbF2 after ex situ heating to 500 °C and subsequent PXRD measurement. These results are consistent with the TGA measurements of our previously reported SLUG-6 structure, where the organic pillars are calcined out of the structure, constituting the major weight loss event. For both structures, there are gradual and relatively sudden weight gain steps observed around the temperature ranges from 250 °C to the major mass loss events (445 and 454 °C) and also ca. 800 °C up to around 900 °C, respectively. These events may be due to uptake of N2(g).

The small weight loss of ~1% with onset at ca. 100 °C is most likely due to physisorbed water. The only significant weight loss step of 6% beginning at 456 °C is attributed to 71% of the perchlorate anions being evolved from the galleries of the structure (8.4% expected if 100% of the perchlorate anions). The structure becomes destabilized as the anions are driven out, transforming the layers into α-PbF2 (ICDD PDF No. 41-1086) as evidenced by ex situ heating to 450 °C and subsequent PXRD. The major weight loss at ca. 860 °C and continuing through the entire trace up to the maximum measurable temperature of 1000 °C is indicative of the thermal decomposition of the PbF2 structure. From the literature, the α-PbF2 structure is stable to 500 °C, where gradual weight loss begins and about 10% of the mass is lost when it reaches 800 °C. Presumably, fluorine (F2) is being evolved and the structure is condensing into lead metal.

The TGA trace of SLUG-11 shows thermal stability up to ca. 445 °C (Figure ). After the major weight loss just beyond 500 °C, about 75% of the original mass remains. This corresponds to 81% of the propanedisulfonate molecules (theoretically 31% of entire structure). The TGA trace of SLUG-12 shows that the structure remains thermally stable up to ca. 454 °C (Figure ). The major weight loss step leaves about 73% of the original mass. This would correspond to 84% of the butanedisulfonate molecules (32% theoretical). Both of the structures were found to be α-PbF2 after ex situ heating to 500 °C and subsequent PXRD measurement. These results are consistent with the TGA measurements of our previously reported SLUG-6 structure, where the organic pillars are calcined out of the structure, constituting the major weight loss event.
